Eco-driving Incentive Mechanisms for Mitigating Emissions in Urban Transportation

M. Umar B. Niazi, Jung-Hoon Cho, Munther A. Dahleh, Roy Dong, and Cathy Wu M. U. B. Niazi is with the Laboratory for Information and Decision Systems, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, USA, and with the Division of Decision and Control Systems, Digital Futures, KTH Royal Institute of Technology, SE-100 44 Stockholm, Sweden. Emails: niazi@mit.edu, mubniazi@kth.seJ.-H. Cho and C. Wu are with the Laboratory for Information and Decision Systems, Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, USA. Email: jhooncho@mit.edu, cathywu@mit.eduM. A. Dahleh is with the Laboratory for Information and Decision Systems, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, USA. Email: dahleh@mit.eduR. Dong is with the Department of Industrial and Enterprise Systems Engineering, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL 61801, USA. Email: roydong@illinois.eduThis work was partially supported by the European Union’s Horizon Research and Innovation Programme under Marie Skłodowska-Curie grant agreement No. 101062523, the National Science Foundation (NSF) under grant number 2149548, and the Kwanjeong scholarship.
Abstract

This paper proposes incentive mechanisms that promote eco-driving in transportation networks with the over-arching objective of minimizing emissions. The transportation system operator provides the drivers with energy-efficient driving guidance throughout their trips, and their eco-driving levels are measured by how closely they follow this guidance via vehicle telematics. Drivers choose their eco-driving levels to optimize a combination of their travel times and their emissions. To obtain optimal budget allocation and recommendations for the incentive mechanism, the system operator gathers drivers’ preferences, or types, to assess each driver’s trip urgency and natural willingness to eco-drive. In a setting where drivers truthfully report their types, we introduce the first-best incentive mechanism and show that the obedience condition holds (i.e., drivers find it optimal to comply with the system operator’s recommendations) when the recommended eco-driving profile constitutes a Nash equilibrium. Moreover, in a setting where drivers can strategically report their types, we introduce the second-best incentive mechanism and show that the proposed mechanism is incentive-compatible (i.e., drivers find it optimal to be truthful). Under this mechanism, we also show that all equilibrium outcomes are at least as good as the recommended eco-driving profile in terms of the system operator’s objective. Overall, this work offers a framework for designing eco-driving incentive mechanisms while considering both the strategic behavior of individual drivers and the network effects of collective decision-making.

Index Terms:
Incentive design, eco-driving, urban transportation, Nash equilibrium, obedience, incentive compatibility.

I Introduction

The transportation sector is a major contributor to climate change, accounting for a significant portion – between a quarter and a third – of global greenhouse gas emissions. Urban transportation, in particular, is a growing threat, contributing substantially to these emissions and increasing at an alarming rate of 2-3% annually, [1], despite the rise of electric vehicles. This necessitates immediate action regarding financial investments and the adoption of readily available solutions for sustainable transportation.

Numerous strategies have been employed to improve fuel efficiency and decrease emissions in on-road vehicles. While advancements in engine technology, electrification, and autonomous vehicles hold promise for sustainable transportation, these solutions require significant time and investment. Presently, even electric vehicles rely on an energy grid and raw materials that may not be entirely emissions-free and/or sustainable. Therefore, under these circumstances, eco-driving stands out as an immediate, cost-effective, and highly efficient means of reducing emissions from urban road transportation [2]. Research has consistently demonstrated that eco-driving practices can yield substantial reductions in vehicle emissions, ranging from 10% to as high as 45% [3]. These findings emphasize the significant role that eco-driving can play in addressing the urgent challenge of climate change.

Eco-driving comprises techniques that improve fuel efficiency, which is akin to minimizing emissions [4], by optimizing vehicle operation and driver behavior. These techniques include smoother acceleration, no idling, and maintaining a steady speed. Eco-driving results in lower emissions by circumventing energy losses due to inefficient vehicle operation.

While eco-driving offers significant environmental benefits, it can sometimes lead to longer travel times. This can be a barrier for some drivers to adopt eco-driving because of prioritizing shorter travel times over lower emissions. Therefore, transportation system operators (TSOs) need to consider implementing incentive mechanisms that reward drivers for adopting eco-driving practices. These eco-driving incentive mechanisms (EDIMs) not only encourage drivers to choose eco-friendly driving styles but also contribute to achieving the overall emission reduction goals in transportation networks.

A considerable amount of evidence supports the effectiveness of incentive mechanisms in promoting eco-driving. For instance, [5] observed a reduction of over 10% in fuel consumption and emissions after monetary incentives were introduced to bus drivers for eco-driving. Remarkably, they found out that the cost savings in fuel exceeded the incentives provided to drivers, showing the profitability of EDIMs for bus companies. Comparable results were obtained by [6] and [7] where heavy-duty vehicle drivers were incentivized by logistic companies. Furthermore, behavioral studies, such as [8] and [9], demonstrate that monetary incentives are more effective in changing driver behavior than merely providing informational indicators for eco-driving through in-vehicle interfaces. Nevertheless, the incentive mechanisms presented in this body of literature are overly simplistic and do not cater to various driver types with differing preferences.

To address the variability in driver preferences, our previous work [10] introduced a simulation-assisted EDIM with the overarching goal of reducing emissions in an urban transportation network. After gathering private information from the drivers about their trips and preferences, the TSO computes feasible eco-driving strategies for each driver that minimize the overall emissions of the network subject to budget and obedience constraints. Such an EDIM allows the TSO to provide personalized incentives and eco-driving recommendations to the drivers. This approach is unique in its integration of a traffic simulator into the incentive mechanism, enabling the system operator to predict traffic conditions and compute corresponding eco-driving recommendations and incentives that can potentially reduce emissions. However, the approach presented in [10] does not account for the interactions between the drivers when they eco-drive in a transportation network. In reality, the driving policy of each driver impacts the traffic around her, influencing the driving policies of other drivers, and vice versa. Such an interaction is natural because the drivers usually aim to conform with the surrounding traffic [11, 12, 13]. Moreover, [10] assumes that drivers provide true information about their preferences, which may not hold when they are strategic and aim to maximize their incentive.

In the present paper, we design EDIMs for promoting eco-driving by considering two key challenges: i) interactions between the drivers who share routes, and ii) drivers may provide strategically manipulated data to the TSO to maximize their incentives. The incentive mechanism induces an eco-driving game where drivers choose eco-driving levels that minimize a combination of their travel times and emissions, and maximize their respective incentives. Under the assumption that drivers are truthful or the TSO knows the types of drivers, we design a first-best EDIM that minimizes the overall emissions by incentivizing drivers subject to budget and obedience constraints. The first-best EDIM implements the recommended eco-driving levels at a Nash equilibrium, which is shown to satisfy the obedience constraint, where the drivers find it optimal to comply with the recommended eco-driving levels provided by the TSO. When drivers strategically report their types, we design a second-best EDIM that, in addition to budget and obedience constraints, also satisfies the incentive compatibility constraint, where the drivers find it optimal to report their types truthfully.

We show that the first-best EDIM is implemented in Nash equilibrium in the sense that the recommended eco-driving profile constitutes a Nash equilibrium of the induced eco-driving game. While the first-best EDIM theoretically achieves lower emissions than the second-best, it is impractical due to its vulnerability to strategic reporting of types. In contrast, the second-best EDIM is robust to strategic manipulation and guarantees that all equilibrium outcomes are at least as good as the recommended eco-driving profile.

The paper is organized as follows. Section II describes the model of an eco-driving incentive mechanism. Section III and Section IV propose first-best and second-best EDIMs under truthful and strategic reporting, respectively. Section V presents numerical simulations showing the effect of misreporting and the total incentive budget on eco-driving and emissions. Finally, Section VI presents the concluding remarks.

II Model of Eco-Driving Incentive Mechanism

This section explores the decision-making process that drivers utilize for selecting their eco-driving policies. We first describe how drivers adopt eco-driving policies and how these choices affect their neighboring drivers. When drivers share a route, their choices regarding eco-driving policies can influence each other’s emissions and travel time. We describe a driver’s decision model as one that optimizes a combination of her111We will refer to a driver by she/her and the TSO by he/him. emissions and her travel time. We also model the incentive given by the TSO to each driver and how it shapes her decision model. An incentive mechanism for eco-driving is described by a pair of recommendations and incentives to the drivers. The mechanism induces a game between the drivers where, given the incentives, they choose a Nash equilibrium profile for their eco-driving levels. Finally, we describe the obedience constraint of the incentive mechanism that guarantees driver compliance with the recommended eco-driving levels.

II-A Eco-driving Policy and Interactions

Consider a set of drivers 𝒩={1,…,n}𝒩1…𝑛\mathcal{N}=\{1,\dots,n\}caligraphic_N = { 1 , … , italic_n } in an urban transportation network 𝒢=(ℐ,ℒ)𝒢ℐℒ\mathcal{G}=(\mathcal{I},\mathcal{L})caligraphic_G = ( caligraphic_I , caligraphic_L ), where ℐℐ\mathcal{I}caligraphic_I is the set of intersections and ℒ⊆ℐ×ℐℒℐℐ\mathcal{L}\subseteq\mathcal{I}\times\mathcal{I}caligraphic_L ⊆ caligraphic_I × caligraphic_I is the set of links/roads. Each driver i𝑖iitalic_i chooses a route ℛi={oi,…,di}subscriptℛ𝑖subscript𝑜𝑖…subscript𝑑𝑖\mathcal{R}_{i}=\{o_{i},\dots,d_{i}\}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } to drive between her origin oi∈ℒsubscript𝑜𝑖ℒo_{i}\in\mathcal{L}italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_L and her destination di∈ℒsubscript𝑑𝑖ℒd_{i}\in\mathcal{L}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_L, where di≠oisubscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝑜𝑖d_{i}\neq o_{i}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The driving policy adopted by driver i𝑖iitalic_i, for i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in\mathcal{N}italic_i ∈ caligraphic_N, on her route ℛisubscriptℛ𝑖\mathcal{R}_{i}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is mapped to an eco-driving level ai∈Ai=[0,1]subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝐴𝑖01a_{i}\in A_{i}=[0,1]italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ 0 , 1 ]. Knowing the vehicle types, origins, destinations, and routes of drivers, the TSO uses some digital platform to provide each driver with a personalized eco-driving guidance that results in minimal emissions on her travel journey. If driver i𝑖iitalic_i fully complies with this eco-driving guidance, then we say that her eco-driving level is ai=1subscript𝑎𝑖1a_{i}=1italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1. Deviations from this eco-driving guidance results in an eco-driving level ai<1subscript𝑎𝑖1a_{i}<1italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1. A driver may be inclined to deviate from this eco-driving guidance to, for instance, reduce her travel time. Thus, each driver adopts a driving policy that finds an optimal trade-off between her emissions and travel time. This decision model of drivers will be formalized in Section II-C.

Remark 1.

A wealth of research exists on designing controllers for fuel-efficient or eco-friendly driving [14, 15, 16]. These studies span signalized intersections [17, 18, 4] and extend to connected vehicles [19, 20] and even urban transportation networks [21], all considering varying traffic conditions. This research primarily focuses on eco-driving for autonomous vehicles, which by virtue of being “autonomous” can perfectly comply with the eco-driving policies computed by on-board controllers. However, human drivers may not comply with the eco-driving guidance because of the misalignment of their objectives with the TSO. The objective of the TSO is to minimize the overall emissions of the network, whereas, in addition to minimizing emissions or fuel consumption, the objectives of human drivers also include minimizing their travel time. This misalignment of objectives motivates the need for incentives that encourage drivers to comply with the eco-driving guidance provided by the TSO. ⋄⋄\diamond⋄

II-B Emissions and Travel Time

We assume a monitoring phase comprising multiple trips of the drivers in the past where the TSO uses vehicle telematics to collect data related to the driving behavior of each driver i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in\mathcal{N}italic_i ∈ caligraphic_N. This also includes interactions between drivers based on their daily routes and how different eco-driving policies of drivers affect their emissions and travel times. In an urban setting, collecting this data is meaningful to estimate the emissions and travel time of drivers as functions of their eco-driving levels because of the periodic patterns in the traffic state during weekdays. For instance, drivers drive between their homes and workplaces during certain hours of the weekdays. Remark 2.

Our assumption that the TSO knows emission and travel time functions beforehand is justified. In fact, advances in telematics technology can provide the data required for accurate estimation of these functions. For instance, [22] developed a deep learning method using telematics data to precisely estimate vehicle emissions within a transportation network. Similarly, [23] and [24] use GPS data of vehicles to predict travel times with high accuracy. Even in vehicles without traditional telematics, smartphone-based telematics [25] offers a viable solution for estimating both emissions and travel times. The reader is further referred to [26] for a survey on learning from telematics car driving data. Using the past telematics data, one can also estimate for each driver i𝑖iitalic_i, a joint and marginal probability density functions of her emissions and the eco-driving levels of drivers j∈𝒩i𝑗subscript𝒩𝑖j\in\mathcal{N}_{i}italic_j ∈ caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and of her travel time and the eco-driving levels of drivers j∈𝒩i𝑗subscript𝒩𝑖j\in\mathcal{N}_{i}italic_j ∈ caligraphic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The emissions function xi⁢(ai,a−i)subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑎𝑖x_{i}(a_{i},a_{-i})italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and travel time function yi⁢(ai,a−i)subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑎𝑖y_{i}(a_{i},a_{-i})italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) can then be defined as the conditional expectations with respect to these probability density functions. ⋄⋄\diamond⋄

Remark 3.

Since drivers can easily observe time to destination through navigation apps like Google maps, it is natural to assume that they choose a driving policy that only optimizes their travel time. However, the decision model of drivers considered in (3) assumes that drivers optimize a combination of both emissions and travel time unless θi=1subscript𝜃𝑖1\theta_{i}=1italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 or θi=0subscript𝜃𝑖0\theta_{i}=0italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0. This model is valid because many newer vehicles offer a fuel economy estimation feature on the dashboard that displays the number of kilometers/miles per unit of fuel222The fuel economy feature in some vehicles display the amount of fuel per unit distance (e.g., liters/gallons per 100 kilometers/miles) which is better in terms of representing the economic cost of emissions. See “Accuracy of in-dash fuel estimates” by American Automobile Association, July 2021, for more details. (liter/gallon for combustion engine vehicles and kWh for electric vehicles) based on the style with which the vehicle is being driven. Fuel economy feature provides valuable feedback to the driver – essentially showing how far the car could travel on a single unit of fuel if driven in the same manner as currently. Using this feature, drivers become aware of their fuel consumption and adopt driving policies that increase their fuel economy or, equivalently, decrease their emissions [27]. ⋄⋄\diamond⋄

The task of the TSO is to design an incentive rate function u:Θ→U:𝑢→Θ𝑈u:\Theta\to Uitalic_u : roman_Θ → italic_U, where ui⁢(θ)∈Ui=ℝ+subscript𝑢𝑖𝜃subscript𝑈𝑖subscriptℝu_{i}(\theta)\in U_{i}=\mathbb{R}_{+}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) ∈ italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and U=∏j=1nUj𝑈superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗1𝑛subscript𝑈𝑗U=\prod_{j=1}^{n}U_{j}italic_U = ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for persuading the drivers to increase their eco-driving levels. where cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is given in (3) and ui⁢aisubscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑎𝑖u_{i}a_{i}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the total incentive received by driver i𝑖iitalic_i for choosing an eco-driving level aisubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

We consider traffic conditions in the network where eco-driving leads to extended travel times. For instance, maintaining a smooth, consistent speed can reduce emissions but could take longer compared to more aggressive driving with frequent accelerations [28]. To incentivize eco-friendly driving, the TSO compensates drivers for any additional travel time incurred. It is important to remark that there could be other scenarios, e.g., eco-driving near signalized intersections [17, 18, 4], where eco-driving lowers both the travel time and emissions. However, in these scenarios, drivers do not need incentives to eco-drive according to the emissions-travel time trade-off model considered in (3) and (4).

Example 2.

II-D Eco-driving Game induced by EDIM

The eco-driving incentive mechanism (EDIM) is denoted by (f,u)𝑓𝑢(f,u)( italic_f , italic_u ), where f:Θ→A:𝑓→Θ𝐴f:\Theta\to Aitalic_f : roman_Θ → italic_A is the eco-driving recommendation function that the TSO wants the drivers to comply with, and u:Θ→U:𝑢→Θ𝑈u:\Theta\to Uitalic_u : roman_Θ → italic_U is the incentive function that the TSO proposes to the drivers for eco-driving. Remark 4.

In the incentive design literature, f𝑓fitalic_f is also known as the social choice function. Moreover, when the true types of the drivers are known, the outcome (f⁢(θ),u⁢(θ))𝑓𝜃𝑢𝜃(f(\theta),u(\theta))( italic_f ( italic_θ ) , italic_u ( italic_θ ) ) implemented by the incentive mechanism is called the first-best solution, which will be the focus of Section III. When the true types are unknown, the implemented outcome is called the second-best solution, which will be the focus of Section IV. ⋄⋄\diamond⋄

That is, at the Nash equilibrium, no driver can benefit from unilaterally deviating from their equilibrium eco-driving level ai∗superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i}^{*}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Because of 1, the existence of a Nash equilibrium is guaranteed by Debreu [29], which is restated as follows.

Lemma 1.

Let 1 hold. Then, the eco-driving game (ℓ1,…,ℓn)subscriptℓ1…subscriptℓ𝑛(\ell_{1},\dots,\ell_{n})( roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) admits a Nash equilibrium. ⌟⌟\lrcorner⌟

Although 1 (see a proof in Section -A) guarantees the existence of a Nash equilibrium, it may not be unique. The uniqueness of a Nash equilibrium is guaranteed by the so-called diagonally strict convexity condition by Rosen [30], which can be interpreted as the monotonicity of the vector of gradients of the cost functions ℓisubscriptℓ𝑖\ell_{i}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with respect to aisubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for every i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in\mathcal{N}italic_i ∈ caligraphic_N. This condition is satisfied if the emission xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and travel time yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are strictly convex functions, e.g., (1) and (2).

III First-best Eco-driving Incentive Mechanism

The first-best optimal EDIM is the mechanism that achieves the best outcome when the TSO has perfect knowledge of the drivers’ types [31]. To achieve this, we assume that the drivers truthfully report their types to the TSO. Then, the goal of the TSO is to minimize the overall emissions by recommending a minimum level of eco-driving f1⁢(θ)∈A1,…,fn⁢(θ)∈Anformulae-sequencesubscript𝑓1𝜃subscript𝐴1…subscript𝑓𝑛𝜃subscript𝐴𝑛f_{1}(\theta)\in A_{1},\dots,f_{n}(\theta)\in A_{n}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) ∈ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) ∈ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and respectively allocating the incentives u1⁢(θ)∈U1,…,un⁢(θ)∈Unformulae-sequencesubscript𝑢1𝜃subscript𝑈1…subscript𝑢𝑛𝜃subscript𝑈𝑛u_{1}(\theta)\in U_{1},\dots,u_{n}(\theta)\in U_{n}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) ∈ italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) ∈ italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to the drivers. In this section, we show that the first-best EDIM, which is implemented in Nash equilibrium, is obedient and can be equivalently formulated as a constrained optimization problem.

Even if the existence of a Nash equilibrium is guaranteed by 1, computing a Nash equilibrium profile for a continuous game (ℓ1,…,ℓn)subscriptℓ1…subscriptℓ𝑛(\ell_{1},\dots,\ell_{n})( roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a challenging problem. Ratliff et al. [32] present a gradient-based algorithm that converge to a local Nash equilibrium, which is a weaker notion than the Nash equilibrium. Mertikopoulos and Staudigl in [33, 34] provide a multi-agent online learning algorithm that converges to a Nash equilibrium under a variational condition on the cost functions. Toonsi and Shamma [35] provide different conditions under which distributed gradient-based algorithms with higher-order dynamics can converge to a Nash equilibrium. However, in the incentive mechanism (9), the TSO can induce any Nash equilibrium by allocating incentives u1⁢(θ),…,un⁢(θ)subscript𝑢1𝜃…subscript𝑢𝑛𝜃u_{1}(\theta),\dots,u_{n}(\theta)italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) , … , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) to drivers subject to the budget constraint (9c). Therefore, in this case, the TSO does not need to compute a Nash equilibrium; rather, he chooses one and implements it. In other words, any recommendation f⁢(θ)𝑓𝜃f(\theta)italic_f ( italic_θ ) can be implemented as Nash equilibrium by appropriately incentivizing drivers subject to the budget constraint.

III-C Equivalent Formulation

If the incentivized cost ℓisubscriptℓ𝑖\ell_{i}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of each driver is convex and differentiable in her own decision variable aisubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then a Nash equilibrium of EDG (ℓ1,…,ℓn)subscriptℓ1…subscriptℓ𝑛(\ell_{1},\dots,\ell_{n})( roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) exists and the TSO can implement the EDIM (f,u)𝑓𝑢(f,u)( italic_f , italic_u ) in Nash equilibrium provided that he knows the true types of the drivers. The question that remains is which Nash equilibrium should the TSO implement and how to solve (9). To answer the first question, the TSO should choose the Nash equilibrium that minimizes the overall emissions of the transportation network subject to the budget constraint, i.e., the Nash equilibrium that fits his objective. To answer the second question, first notice that solving (9) directly is challenging because it is a bilevel optimization problem. However, we observe that (9) admits an equivalent formulation as a constrained optimization problem.

IV-A Incentive Compatibility

To make the EDIM (f,u)𝑓𝑢(f,u)( italic_f , italic_u ) resilient to strategic reporting of types, another goal of the TSO, in addition to minimizing emissions, is to design the eco-driving recommendation function f:Θ→A:𝑓→Θ𝐴f:\Theta\to Aitalic_f : roman_Θ → italic_A and the incentive function u:Θ→U:𝑢→Θ𝑈u:\Theta\to Uitalic_u : roman_Θ → italic_U such that the drivers do not gain anything by reporting their types untruthfully. From the discussion above, it might appear that enforcing incentive compatibility constraint comes at a cost. That is, given a fixed total budget b∈ℝ+𝑏subscriptℝb\in\mathbb{R}_{+}italic_b ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, one may argue that the TSO can achieve higher eco-driving levels in the first-best EDIM than in the second-best EDIM. However, this holds only when the drivers report truthfully. When the drivers report strategically, the first-best EDIM may not be obedient anymore, and the drivers may find lower eco-driving levels than the recommended f𝑓fitalic_f to be optimal at an equilibrium. Consequently, the first-best EDIM can result in higher overall emissions compared to the second-best under strategic reporting.

Another observation is that the second-best EDIM (15)-(16) does not implement f𝑓fitalic_f at a Nash equilibrium in a sense that a=f𝑎𝑓a=fitalic_a = italic_f is not a Nash equilibrium. However, since the second-best EDIM is obedient and the EDG it induces has a Nash equilibrium (1), we have that all the Nash equilibria are above the recommendation f𝑓fitalic_f. That is, for every a∗∈A∗superscript𝑎superscript𝐴a^{*}\in A^{*}italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where A∗superscript𝐴A^{*}italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a set of Nash equilibria given by (10), it holds that ai∗≥fisuperscriptsubscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖a_{i}^{*}\geq f_{i}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≥ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for every i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in\mathcal{N}italic_i ∈ caligraphic_N. Therefore, the second-best EDIM implements f𝑓fitalic_f is a Nash equilibrium if we refine the definition of implementation in Nash equilibrium. Under such definition, the mechanism guarantees that any equilibrium action profile will result in eco-driving levels at least as high as the recommended levels f∈A𝑓𝐴f\in Aitalic_f ∈ italic_A.

V Numerical Simulations

This section compares first-best and second-best eco-driving incentive mechanisms. While the first-best EDIM achieves lower emissions than the second-best when drivers report their types truthfully, it is shown to violate the obedience constraint even when a single driver misreports her type. Moreover, under the first-best EDIM, it is optimal for drivers to misreport their types because their recommendations and incentives depends on their respective reported types. Conversely, the second-best EDIM is both obedient and incentive compatible, where not only drivers comply with the recommended eco-driving levels but also find it optimal to truthfully report their types. Nevertheless, the second-best mechanism results in higher overall emissions compared to the first-best when only one driver misreports her type. We demonstrate that this emission gap diminishes as the total budget of the TSO increases.

However, we observe that both the recommended and optimal eco-driving levels of driver i𝑖iitalic_i are in general lower under the second-best EDIM than the first-best. This is because enforcing incentive compatibility constraint, i.e., truthfulness, makes the mechanism conservative. Moreover, the gap between the eco-driving levels of the first-best and the second-best is huge because only one driver is misreporting her type. If the incentive compatibility is not enforced and all drivers misreport their types, the performance of the first-best EDIM will worsen.

In fact, truthful reporting is a Nash equilibrium strategy for i𝑖iitalic_i.

V-C Overall Emissions Reduction with Increased Budget

We demonstrate the effect of the total budget b𝑏bitalic_b on the overall emissions of the network, where we assume that drivers truthfully report their types. Fig. 6 shows the total emissions of drivers under different values of the total budget. There is a decreasing trend because with higher budget, the TSO can implement higher eco-driving levels under both first-best and second-best EDIMs, which results in lower emissions.

Since the first-best EDIM results in higher eco-driving levels than the eco-driving levels of the second-best, we observe in Fig. 6 that with the same budget the first-best EDIM in general achieves lower emissions than the second-best. Moreover, notice that for budget b>7𝑏7b>7italic_b > 7, the emissions under the first-best EDIM converges to a constant value. This is because with large budget, the TSO can in principal incentivize all the drivers to choose maximum eco-driving levels a=f⁢(θ)=1n𝑎𝑓𝜃subscript1𝑛a=f(\theta)=1_{n}italic_a = italic_f ( italic_θ ) = 1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where they fully comply with the eco-driving guidance. On the other hand, under the second-best EDIM, a=f⁢(θ)=1n𝑎𝑓𝜃subscript1𝑛a=f(\theta)=1_{n}italic_a = italic_f ( italic_θ ) = 1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is achieved for budget b>9𝑏9b>9italic_b > 9.

In conclusion, if the TSO has sufficiently large budget, he can incentivize drivers to opt for maximum eco-driving levels with full compliance to the eco-driving guidance. However, under the second-best EDIM, the budget amount required to ensure full compliance is larger than the amount required by the first-best EDIM with known types. Therefore, in addition to the emission cost demonstrated in Fig. 6, the TSO also incurs additional budget cost to incentivize similar levels of eco-driving when drivers report their types strategically.

VI Concluding Remarks

This paper addressed the challenge of incentivizing eco-driving with the overarching goal of minimizing emissions in urban transportation networks. We proposed incentive mechanisms that encourage drivers to adopt more fuel-efficient and eco-friendly driving behavior. The timeline of the incentive mechanisms is as follows: 1) the TSO elicits preferences or types from the drivers, 2) the TSO computes eco-driving levels that minimize the overall emissions subject to the limited budget which is to be optimally allocated as incentives to the drivers, and 3) the TSO provides each driver with the recommended eco-driving level that she needs to comply with and offers an incentive rate that shapes her cost function. When the drivers truthfully report their types, the first-best EDIM implements the recommended eco-driving levels at Nash equilibrium, which implies obedience in a sense that drivers find it optimal to choose their eco-driving levels at least as high as the recommended levels. However, when the drivers strategically report their types, the obedience constraint may not hold. Therefore, the second-best EDIM, in addition to ensuring obedience constraint, also incorporates the incentive compatibility constraint, which guarantees that the drivers do not gain any advantage by misreporting their types. Since the second-best EDIM is robust, it is conservative and in general requires more budget to achieve the similar outcomes as the first-best EDIM.

However, it needs to be clarified that the first-best EDIM achieves lower emissions than the second-best only when the drivers are assumed to be truthful. In general, it is impractical because of its vulnerability to strategic misreporting. On the other hand, the second-best EDIM ensures that irrespective of the reported types, the equilibrium eco-driving profile of drivers in the induced eco-driving game is larger than the recommended levels obtained by the mechanism.

This work offers a framework for promoting eco-driving that considers both network effects and driver behavior. By incorporating strategic considerations and individual preferences, the proposed mechanisms provide a robust and effective approach to achieving sustainable urban transportation. Although the proposed incentive mechanisms are direct, where drivers directly report their types to the TSO, indirect mechanisms can also be considered, where the TSO observes the driving behavior of drivers to infer their types. However, from the analysis point-of-view, implementation of both mechanisms is equivalent thanks to the revelation principal. Nonetheless, indirect mechanisms are more practical, which will be explored in our future work.
